member.name: IAudioRenderClient.GetBuffer
member.summary: Retrieves a pointer to the next available space in the rendering endpoint buffer into which the caller can write a data packet.
member.param: The number of audio frames in the data packet that the caller plans to write to the requested space in the buffer. If the call succeeds, the size of the buffer area pointed to by *ppData matches the size specified in NumFramesRequested.
Pointer to a pointer variable into which the method writes the starting address of the buffer area into which the caller will write the data packet.

returns.para: If the method succeeds, it returns S_OK. If it fails, possible return codes include, but are not limited to, the values shown in the following table.

listheader.description: failed to retrieve a data buffer and *ppData points to NULL. For more information, see Remarks.
The NumFramesRequested value exceeds the available buffer space (buffer size minus padding size).
The stream is exclusive mode and uses event-driven buffering, but the client attempted to get a packet that was not the size of the buffer.
A previous IAudioRenderClient.GetBuffer call is still in effect.
The audio endpoint device has been unplugged, or the audio hardware or associated hardware resources have been reconfigured, disabled, removed, or otherwise made unavailable for use.
Buffer cannot be accessed because a stream reset is in progress.
The Windows audio service is not running.

member.name: IAudioRenderClient.ReleaseBuffer
member.summary: The ReleaseBuffer method releases the buffer space acquired in the previous call to the method.
member.param: The number of audio frames written by the client to the data packet. The value of this parameter must be less than or equal to the size of the data packet, as specified in the NumFramesRequested parameter passed to the method.

param.name: dwFlags
param.para: The buffer-configuration flags. The caller can set this parameter either to 0 or to the following enumeration value (a flag bit):

If this flag bit is set, the audio engine treats the data packet as though it contains silence regardless of the data values contained in the packet. This flag eliminates the need for the client to explicitly write silence data to the rendering buffer.

summary.para: The IAudioRenderClient interface enables a client to write output data to a rendering endpoint buffer. The client obtains a reference to the IAudioRenderClient interface of a stream object by calling the method with parameter riid set to REFIID IID_IAudioRenderClient.

The methods in this interface manage the movement of data packets that contain audio-rendering data. The length of a data packet is expressed as the number of audio frames in the packet. The size of an audio frame is specified by the nBlockAlign member of the WAVEFORMATEX structure that the client obtains by calling the method. The size in bytes of an audio frame equals the number of channels in the stream multiplied by the sample size per channel. For example, the frame size is four bytes for a stereo (2-channel) stream with 16-bit samples. A packet always contains an integral number of audio frames.
When releasing an IAudioRenderClient interface instance, the client must call the interface's Release method from the same thread as the call to IAudioClient.GetService that created the object.
